neighbors.name: Christopher E. Wondree & Emily C. Wondree
neighbors.claims: Christopher and Emily Wondree are listed as co-owners of a residential parcel in Spotsylvania County ([apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov](https://apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov/assessment/assessment/index.cfm#:~:text=)). Their names have not surfaced in local news or public meetings about development, suggesting they have not taken a visible stance on such issues ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=Locals%2C%20many%20from%20the%20gated,the%20character%20of%20their%20home)). They were not identified among the neighbors who organized against a recent large solar project in the county ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=Locals%2C%20many%20from%20the%20gated,the%20character%20of%20their%20home)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Offer a personal briefing emphasizing that the project will respect the area’s rural character and not harm property values ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=Locals%2C%20many%20from%20the%20gated,the%20character%20of%20their%20home)). A neighborly, informal approach at their residence could help address any concerns in a low-pressure setting.

neighbors.name: Santos A. Bonilla & Jessica L. Bonilla
neighbors.claims: Santos Bonilla is a Fredericksburg-area professional, working as a Senior Solutions Engineer at Oracle ([www.idcrawl.com](https://www.idcrawl.com/santos-bonilla#:~:text=Santos%20Bonilla)). The Bonillas have no record of speaking in county hearings or media about development proposals ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=As%20a%20proposal%20to%20construct,growing%20demand%20for%20renewable%20energy)). They do not hold any known public offices or leadership positions in the community ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=As%20a%20proposal%20to%20construct,growing%20demand%20for%20renewable%20energy)).
neighbors.influence_justification: No civic appointments or media presence

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out one-on-one with clear, factual information, as they have kept a low public profile ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=As%20a%20proposal%20to%20construct,growing%20demand%20for%20renewable%20energy)). Emphasize how the project will not disrupt the neighborhood’s peace or home values, which can address likely concerns.

neighbors.name: Hugh Francis Develin
neighbors.claims: Hugh F. Develin is identified as the sole owner of parcel 21J-1-17 in Spotsylvania, according to county real estate records ([apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov](https://apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov/assessment/assessment/index.cfm#:~:text=)). There is no evidence of Develin taking part in local government boards or voicing opinions on development projects in public forums ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=As%20a%20proposal%20to%20construct,growing%20demand%20for%20renewable%20energy)). His name does not appear in reports of citizen groups either supporting or opposing local land-use changes ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=This%20January%2C%20the%20Spotsylvania%20Planning,the%20making%2C%20will%20go%20forward)).
neighbors.influence_justification: No public profile or group involvement

approach_recommendations.engage: Respect his privacy and communicate project details in a manner that acknowledges community character. If he is a long-term resident, underscore that the project design is sensitive to preserving the area’s traditional feel ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=Locals%2C%20many%20from%20the%20gated,the%20character%20of%20their%20home)).

neighbors.name: John Stanley Dominski & Kylie Ann Dominski
neighbors.claims: John and Kylie Dominski jointly own a residential lot (parcel 21M-2-18) in Spotsylvania County ([apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov](https://apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov/assessment/assessment/index.cfm#:~:text=)). They have not been mentioned in local newspapers or county meeting minutes regarding development issues ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=As%20a%20proposal%20to%20construct,growing%20demand%20for%20renewable%20energy)). No public statements or civic roles for the Dominskis were found in the course of research, indicating they stay out of spotlight on community matters ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=This%20January%2C%20the%20Spotsylvania%20Planning,the%20making%2C%20will%20go%20forward)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Private individuals, no noted civic activity

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Dominskis early with open information sessions to preempt any misinformation ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=This%20January%2C%20the%20Spotsylvania%20Planning,the%20making%2C%20will%20go%20forward)). A small neighborhood meeting or open house format can help build trust, showing that their concerns about peace and home investment are being heard.

neighbors.claims: John A. Buckner III and Micala Peterson are co-owners of parcel 21M-2-21 in Spotsylvania (per the county’s property records) ([apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov](https://apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov/assessment/assessment/index.cfm#:~:text=)). Neither individual has a public history of engaging in development disputes or local political activities ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=As%20a%20proposal%20to%20construct,growing%20demand%20for%20renewable%20energy)). approach_recommendations.engage: Approach them in a collaborative manner that emphasizes local input and transparency ([www.newsfromthestates.com](https://www.newsfromthestates.com/article/virginias-biggest-proposed-solar-project-also-among-its-most-contentious-local-land-use#:~:text=As%20a%20proposal%20to%20construct,growing%20demand%20for%20renewable%20energy)). Present the project’s benefits and protections for property values, reinforcing that the community’s voice is respected in the process.

neighbors.name: Michael B. Tierney
neighbors.claims: Michael B. Tierney is based in the Fredericksburg area and works as an independent contractor in real estate ([projects.propublica.org](https://projects.propublica.org/coronavirus/bailouts/loans/michael-b-tierney-1389717901#:~:text=Fredericksburg%2C%20VA)). He obtained a ~$7,000 Paycheck Protection Program loan in June 2020 (first-round COVID-19 relief), which was fully forgiven ([projects.propublica.org](https://projects.propublica.org/coronavirus/bailouts/loans/michael-b-tierney-1389717901#:~:text=Loan%20Amount)) ([projects.propublica.org](https://projects.propublica.org/coronavirus/bailouts/loans/michael-b-tierney-1389717901#:~:text=Date%20Approved)). No public record was found of Tierney speaking about local development proposals ([www.spotsylvania.va.us](https://www.spotsylvania.va.us/1261/Meeting-Minutes#:~:text=Skip%20to%20Main%20Content%20Early,Read%20On)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a peer from the real estate community reach out to discuss how the project could positively impact property values and market trends in the area.

neighbors.name: James C. Leigh Jr. & Sherry A. Leigh
neighbors.claims: James C. Leigh Jr. and Sherry A. Leigh own a single-family home on a 1.64-acre lot (built in 1989)【Redfin listing — company, retrieved 2025-11-26; "1989 Year Built … 1.64 acres Lot Size"】. No public record of their involvement in local civic affairs or development debates was found【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "69 were against the project and 24 in favor"】.

approach_recommendations.engage: Provide reassurances that the project will be a quiet neighbor with no harm to property values【Spotsylvania County Board Agenda — gov, retrieved 2025-11-26; "solar energy facility … a safe, clean, quiet neighbor"】【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "property values will decline"】.

neighbors.name: James S. McKinney & Jennifer A. Switzsy
neighbors.claims: James S. McKinney and Jennifer A. Switzsy own a residential parcel in the vicinity of the proposed solar farm, but neither has publicly weighed in on the project【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "69 were against the project and 24 in favor"】.

approach_recommendations.engage: Invite them to a personal briefing to explain that local home values and quality of life will be protected during the project【Spotsylvania County Board Agenda — gov, retrieved 2025-11-26; "solar energy facility … a safe, clean, quiet neighbor"】【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "property values will decline"】.

neighbors.name: Justin R. Gumbs
neighbors.claims: Justin R. Gumbs’s property lies on the western side of the project area, where longtime neighbors (e.g., Michael O’Bier) have voiced concerns about the facility’s proximity【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "solar’s not the way to go in a residential area"】. He has no known history of participating in public meetings or statements on local development issues【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "69 were against the project and 24 in favor"】.

approach_recommendations.engage: Encourage a one-on-one conversation (or site visit) to show planned visual buffers and low noise, easing any worries about the project’s impact on his surroundings【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2019-04-10; "before and after visual simulation of the projects"】【Spotsylvania County Board Agenda — gov, retrieved 2025-11-26; "safe, clean, quiet neighbor"】.

neighbors.name: Robert William Gunia & Catherine Michele Gunia
neighbors.claims: Robert W. Gunia and Catherine M. Gunia are listed as owners of parcel 21-A-95B in Spotsylvania County (in the same tax map area as Chancellor Road)【Spotsylvania County Special Commissioner’s Sale — court, retrieved 2025-11-26; "7836 Chancellor Road, Tax Map 21-A-57"】. No references to the Gunia family were found in local meeting minutes or news reports concerning the development【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "69 were against the project and 24 in favor"】.

approach_recommendations.engage: Reassure them with specific plans to mitigate construction impacts, such as limits on heavy traffic and strict erosion-control measures during the build phase【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2019-04-10; "buffer width … Sunday work restrictions"】【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "increased erosion and traffic during the construction phase"】.

neighbors.name: Allan T. Thorburn & Patricia S. Thorburn
neighbors.claims: Allan Thayer Thorburn, 81, was a member of a multi-generational Spotsylvania family of landowners and passed away in 2024【Free Lance–Star obituary — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "Allan Thayer Thorburn, 81, of Spotsylvania County, passed"】【Spotsylvania Memory blog — other, retrieved 2025-11-26; "Mungo William Thorburn (1857–1940) … lived on a large farm"】. His family’s local prominence is reflected in his late father Tom Thorburn’s role as a principal in the Fredericksburg & Wilderness Telephone Company【Spotsylvania Memory blog — other, retrieved 2025-11-26; "principal stockholders of the Fredericksburg & Wilderness Telephone Company"】.

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected local figure (e.g., an agricultural extension agent or county official) explain the robust decommissioning and land-restoration guarantees in place, aligning the project with his family’s long-term land stewardship values【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "application includes a lengthy decommissioning plan and bonds"】【Virginia Mercury — news, retrieved 2025-11-26; "out of context with the rural and historical nature"】.

neighbors.name: Samantha D. Harrell & Kenneth D. Harrell
neighbors.claims: The Harrells reside on Shawmont Road in Fredericksburg (Spotsylvania County) and their home was newly built around 2022 in the Thorburn Estates subdivision ([www.idcrawl.com](https://www.idcrawl.com/samantha-harrell#:~:text=IDCrawl%20www,yahoo.com%20%E2%80%94%20%28770%29%20789)) ([www.zillow.com](https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/7805-Shawmont-Rd-Fredericksburg-VA-22407/2060441486_zpid/#:~:text=...Permanent%20,Subdivision%3A%20Thorburn%20Estates)). approach_recommendations.engage: Begin with a friendly, informal introduction to share project information. Emphasize transparency and listen to any concerns privately, since they have not voiced opinions publicly.

neighbors.claims: Andrew J. Czaplicki and Nicole M. Czaplicki are listed as the owners of a Spotsylvania County parcel ([gis.spotsylvania.va.us](https://gis.spotsylvania.va.us/arcgis/rest/services/PublicHearingCases/Public_Hearing_Mailing_List/FeatureServer/0#:~:text=true%2C%20length%3A%203%2C%20defaultValue%3A%20null%2C,defaultValue%3A%20null%2C%20modelName%3A%20STATE)). No public records or media mentions suggest that the Czaplickis have taken any position on development or energy projects ([www.lynchandsonswalledlake.com](https://www.lynchandsonswalledlake.com/obituaries/Loren-Czaplicki?obId=23040612#:~:text=Obituary%20information%20for%20Loren%20Czaplicki,Obituary)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach with open-ended questions and provide information, as they have no known stance or influence.

neighbors.name: Johanna K Evans Or Darrell W Evans B C Stanley Or N D Stanley Trustees
neighbors.claims: This entry represents a private family land trust managed by individual trustees (Johanna K. Evans, Darrell W. Evans, B.C. Stanley, N.D. Stanley)【5†L2-L9; "records are public information"】. **See RESIDENT table** for details on these individuals, as the property is held personally rather than by an incorporated organization. No public stance on development is documented (the owners are not an organized entity), and their community influence is limited to their ownership of the land. Beneficial owner identity is simply the named trustees, with no broader corporate structure; therefore, specific motivators or engagement approaches cannot be determined from public records ([apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov](https://apps.spotsylvaniacountyva.gov/assessment/assessment/index.cfm#:~:text=,or%20misuse%20of%20this%20data)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Private family trust with individual trustees; no organizational presence or known community role

approach_recommendations.engage: N/A (individual ownership; not profiled as an organization)

neighbors.name: Salem Fields Community Church
neighbors.claims: Salem Fields Community Church is a long-established religious organization (affiliated with the Church of the Nazarene) that has been active in Spotsylvania since 1963【12†L36-L43; "religious organization ... founded in 1963"】. The church has grown substantially – it undertook major campus expansions (adding ~40,000 sq ft of facilities) with new buildings opened in 2008 to support its ministries【79†L33-L40; "addition of 40,000 sf ... opened in 2008"】. The congregation portrays itself as positively engaged with the community and not focused on opposition ("For people. For our community. For Spotsy." is a church slogan)【13†L17-L24; "For people. For our community. For Spotsy."】. In fact, the church’s property is currently being advertised as an “industrial or renewable energy” development site, indicating the church’s openness to such development or a willingness to sell its land for that purpose【54†L7-L12; "11120 Gordon Rd - Industrial use or renewable energy site"】. There is no record of the church formally opposing local development projects; its stance is generally oriented toward community service and growth of its religious mission rather than political activism.
neighbors.influence_justification: Significant local congregation with large facilities and community presence, but primarily focused on ministry (not political activism)

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the church’s leadership (senior pastor or board of trustees) in dialogue; emphasize how the development can benefit the community or align with the church’s values; if the church is considering land sale, explore a mutually beneficial arrangement or partnership (e.g., ensure the project is respectful of church activities or offer support for their relocation/facility needs)

neighbors.name: Virginia Electric & Power Company
neighbors.claims: Virginia Electric & Power Company (VEPCO) is the regulated electric utility serving the area, operating as part of Dominion Energy’s system【58†L1-L4; "Virginia Electric and Power Company (VEPCO) (1925–1983)"】. The parcel in question (21-A-93A) is owned by VEPCO and is used for electrical infrastructure (there is a Dominion substation adjacent to the Salem Fields church, accessed through the church’s property)【79†L24-L30; "Access to the substation is through the church site"】. Dominion/VEPCO wields considerable influence in Virginia – for instance, Dominion’s political action committee contributed $200,000 to a state PAC in 2021, reflecting its broad political reach【60†L1-L5; "Dominion’s ... contributed $200,000 ... PAC"】. However, in local land use matters the utility typically remains neutral unless its facilities are directly affected; there’s no public indication that Dominion (via VEPCO) is taking any stance on nearby development. Its primary interest would be ensuring grid reliability and accommodating any new project’s interconnection needs, rather than engaging in community opposition or support campaigns.
neighbors.influence_justification: Dominant regional utility with major economic and political clout (as part of Dominion Energy), though its local parcel is just a substation and it seldom intervenes in local land disputes

approach_recommendations.engage: Maintain open coordination with Dominion/VEPCO on any technical requirements (e.g., interconnection, easements); ensure the project does not impede their infrastructure. Given Dominion’s general neutrality, focus on addressing any operational concerns they might have so they remain indifferent or possibly cooperative regarding the development

neighbors.name: Stacybilt Homes LLC
neighbors.claims: Stacybilt Homes LLC is a Virginia limited liability company that appears to be a small local homebuilder or land investor holding parcel 21M-2-D (likely for future residential development). There is little public information on this entity – it is not prominent in local builder associations or media, suggesting a modest operation (possibly a single-project or family-run developer). As a landowner anticipating home construction, Stacybilt’s interest would be to preserve the desirability and value of its parcel. Such owners often worry that industrial or utility-scale projects nearby could diminish residential property appeal; the conversion of land to an “industrial” use (like a large energy facility) can adversely affect neighboring property values【56†L1-L5; "conversion ... to an industrial site can adversely affect ... property values"】. No record of political donations or community initiatives by this LLC was found. Its stance on development is inferred to be protective: it would likely oppose any project perceived to lower the market value or attractiveness of its future homes, unless adequately compensated or mitigated.
neighbors.influence_justification: Limited-profile local LLC with a small landholding; not a major employer or donor, influence largely tied to its potential as a future developer of its parcel

approach_recommendations.engage: Identify and approach the principal/owner of Stacybilt Homes LLC (via state corporate records or local contacts); acknowledge their development plans and offer assurances or incentives (e.g., buffer zones, aesthetic screenings) to alleviate concerns about property value impacts. If the entity is open to selling the land, consider a purchase or partnership to integrate their parcel into the project to avoid conflict

neighbors.name: Antioch Salem Fields Fred VA LLC C/O Antioch Plan Developers LLC
neighbors.claims: Antioch Salem Fields Fred VA LLC is a special-purpose LLC associated with a developer (noted by the "c/o Antioch Plan Developers LLC" in its address). This suggests it was created for a planned project in the Salem Fields area, managed by an outside development firm. Public records on this entity are sparse – the affiliated company, Antioch Plan Developers, has virtually no local track record (0 projects in the past year and only 1 known project in recent years)【38†L13-L18; "0 projects ... 1 projects in recent years"】 – indicating that this is likely a speculative land investment or a new entrant into the market. The beneficial owners are not disclosed beyond the LLC’s name, implying out-of-region investors or developers are involved. With a presumably residential or commercial development intent for parcel 21-A-93B, this entity’s stance would be to protect its project’s viability and land value. It is likely to oppose any neighboring development (such as a utility-scale energy project) that it perceives could hinder its own development plans or reduce the property’s value. Like other developers, its motivation is profit-driven; we can expect it to act (through legal appeals or community lobbying) if a project threatens to "change" the area in a way that undermines their investment【56†L1-L5; "conversion ... to an industrial site can adversely affect ... property values"】. There are no indications of local philanthropic or political engagement by this LLC – its influence would be exerted mainly via land use attorneys or planning processes to advance or protect its development interests.
neighbors.influence_justification: Out-of-town developer with no established local presence; influence would come only from hired expertise (lawyers, consultants) in land use proceedings rather than community ties or political clout

approach_recommendations.engage: Research and reach out to the development firm behind "Antioch Plan Developers LLC" to identify the key decision-makers. Engage them early to understand their development timeline and concerns; explore a win-win solution (for example, coordinating project plans or offering to purchase their parcel at a premium) to preempt opposition. Given their likely willingness to defend their investment, be prepared for formal objections – retaining a land use attorney and being ready to address zoning or impact claims will be important if negotiations do not lead to a partnership

overview_summary: None of the five profiled neighbors have a clearly documented stance on local development or clean energy projects. All appear to be private residents without notable public roles, indicating generally low community influence. No outspoken supporters or opponents were identified among them, and high-influence community figures are absent in this group. None of the five nearby landowners have a clear public stance on the proposed development, as no explicit support or opposition has been documented. Their community influence appears limited – none hold public office or prominent civic roles – although one couple owns substantial land which could confer some local sway. None of these five neighbors has taken a public stance for or against the development, so their positions remain unknown. Four are private residents with low community influence, while one (Thorburn) carries moderate influence due to longstanding local roots and landownership. None of these five adjacent landowners has taken a public position for or against the proposed development, so all are categorized with an unknown stance. Their community influence is limited – none hold prominent local roles, and all appear to be relatively new residents with modest public profiles. All five neighboring landowners have no clearly documented stance on the proposed development, as none were found to have made public comments or taken positions in local forums. Their influence in the community appears low, with no high-profile roles or notable community leadership among them. This suggests outreach will need to be personalized since none are established community influencers or vocal development critics. The neighboring landowners include a private family trust (individual trustees), a large community church, the state’s primary electric utility, a local homebuilding LLC, and an out-of-area development LLC. The church (a 1963-founded Nazarene congregation) ([www.causeiq.com](https://www.causeiq.com/organizations/salem-fields-community%2C546134188/#:~:text=Salem%20Fields%20Community%20is%20a,that%20was%20founded%20in%201963)) and the utility (Dominion Energy’s Virginia arm) ([www.axios.com](https://www.axios.com/2021/10/16/virginia-energy-giant-quietly-boosts-mcauliffe#:~:text=Virginia%20Democrat%20Terry%20McAuliffe%20publicly,group%20with%20connections%20to%20prominent)) are established community presences, whereas the homebuilder and the development LLC appear to be holding land for investment. The nonprofit church is even marketing its land for industrial/energy use ([www.loopnet.com](https://www.loopnet.com/Listing/11120-Gordon-Rd-Fredericksburg-VA/27706940/#:~:text=11120%20Gordon%20Rd%2C%20Fredericksburg%2C%20VA,Industrial%20use%20or%20renewable%20energy)), while the development LLC has minimal project history (suggesting speculative intent) ([www.levelset.com](https://www.levelset.com/property-owners/antioch-plan-developers-llc/#:~:text=Antioch%20Plan%20Developers%2C%20LLC%20Overview)). Potential opposition funding or activism would most likely come from the profit-driven landholders (the homebuilder and the outside developer) if they perceive new development as harming their property values ([www.essexcca.com](https://www.essexcca.com/industrial-solar-farms#:~:text=Alliance%20www,As%20noted%20in%20the)), whereas the church and utility are less inclined to openly oppose projects.
